question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Let $\mathbf{R}$ be the matrix for rotating about the origin counter-clockwise by an angle of $58^\circ.$  Find $\det \mathbf{R}.$
inference:
The matrix for rotating about the origin counter-clockwise by an angle of $\theta$ is given by
$$\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$$
In this case, $\theta = 58^\circ.$  The matrix is
$$\begin{pmatrix} \cos 58^\circ & -\sin 58^\circ \\ \sin 58^\circ & \cos 58^\circ \end{pmatrix}.$$
The determinant is
$$ (\cos 58^\circ)(\cos 58^\circ) - (-\sin 58^\circ)(\sin 58^\circ) = \cos^2 58^\circ + \sin^2 58^\circ = 1.$$
Final Answer: $\boxed{1}$
ground_truth:
The matrix corresponding to rotating about the origin counter-clockwise by an angle of $\theta$ is given by
\[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.\]The determinant of this matrix is then
\[\cos^2 \theta - (-\sin \theta)(\sin \theta) = \cos^2 \theta + \sin^2 \theta = \boxed{1}.\](Why does this make sense geometrically?)

The determinant of a $2 \times 2$ matrix $\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}$ is $ad-bc$.
The matrix for rotating about the origin counter-clockwise by an angle of $\theta$ is $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}$.
In this case, $\theta = 58^\circ$. The matrix is
$$ \begin{pmatrix} \cos 58^\circ & -\sin 58^\circ \\ \sin 58^\circ & \cos 58^\circ \end{pmatrix}. $$
The determinant of this matrix is
$$ (\cos 58^\circ)(\cos 58^\circ) - (-\sin 58^\circ)(\sin 58^\circ) = \cos^2 58^\circ + \sin^2 58^\circ = 1. $$

Final Answer: $\boxed{1}$
